blog_desc: a contemporary church in Lafayette, Indiana helping people find full life in Christ

posts.alt_excerpt: Since last Fall, we have been talking about the need for us to finally get into a building of our own. We have discussed the need to have a building with more space, we have discussed the fact that it's cheaper to own than to rent, and we have gone through an extensive process of…
posts.author: Pastor Jeff
posts.content:
Since last Fall, we have been talking about the need for us to finally get into a building of our own. We have discussed the need to have a building with more space, we have discussed the fact that it's cheaper to own than to rent, and we have gone through an extensive process of studying God's word together and asking people to make personal financial commitments all in the hope that God would open a door of opportunity for us. I'm beginning to think he has done just that. In just the past three weeks, we have become aware of the building at 2301 Concord Road and the potential that building has to become our new home. Now, to take a step back, I need to tell you that when we finished the pledge drive portion of our capital campaign, it was difficult for me to fight back the feelings of disappointment. We had a goal to raise $550,000 in our pledge drive, but the actual pledges we have raised as of today are $135,001. That's a far cry from the $550,000 we were trying to raise, but I had posted something to our FAQ that is really relevant today...

What if we don't raise enough money?

Strangely, Pastor Jeff is not worried about this. He’s fully convinced that God is going to provide for us the amount of money He thinks we should have at this point in time.However, if we don’t get enough commitments to reach our goal, that must mean that God’s plan for us is different from what we had been thinking. If we don’t reach our goal, we will take that as a sign from God of the following things:
  1. It must not be time for us to consider building a building on the southside.
  2. It must be time for us to reconsider how we can maximize the space we are in or look again for alternate meeting space.
  3. Perhaps God wants us to simply save up the money as we keep our eyes open for the opportunity he will bring our way.
In light of our actual campaign totals, we put our dreams of financing new construction on the back burner, started looking again for a meeting space, started new negotiations with our landlord, and kept our eyes open for other opportunities. Well, we believe God led Pastor Billy to find a listing on a local real estate website for the building at 2301 Concord, and you should know some of these amazing statistics:
  • This building is 10,700 square feet. When we started the process last Summer of praying for and looking for a new location for us, our target building size was 10,000 square feet!
  • This building has a listed purchase price of $500,000. That's the amount we thought we needed so that we could finance a $3M building, but when we didn't reach that target, our financial coach encouraged us to just trust that God would provide the $500,000 somehow over the next three years.
  • The owner has agreed to sell it to us for $400,000! That's a 20% discount right off the bat meaning that we can finance the building with only $25,000 as a downpayment.
  • Based on these numbers and our relationship with the Cornerstone Fund, we believe we will be able to fully fund the purchase and the renovation of this property with money we already have on hand!
  • Finally, after taking possession of this property, we expect to save $2000 per month compared to our current rent!
Amazingly enough, all the numbers seem to be lining up just perfectly to make us believe that God has put this opportunity in front of us.

Some Photos

Click a photo to see a larger version. [gallery link="none" ids="4497,4501,4503,4502,4514,4508,4506,4507,4511,4510,4505"]

There's just one problem...

However, in spite of all these awesome things, there is one major concern: location. Of course, they say that location is the most important consideration in all real estate, and from one perspective this location is amazing. The building is visible from the mall, and it is near the Toys R Us. However, from another perspective, there's a problem. The building is also right next to an adult gift store and a strip club. Jen and I have always been confused at the juxtaposition of these two "adult" businesses right next to the Toys R Us, and the thought of putting our church right next to them too, is a little strange and upsetting at first. Honestly, the thought of moving our church home next door to these businesses has caused a great deal of concern in my heart and in the hearts of other key leaders in our church. Of course, the entire reason we exist as a church is to try to help people discover life in Christ rather than in all the poor substitutes this world offers us. In that light, it may be a perfect act of grace on our part to move right next to a business that is filled with potentially misguided and needy people each night. However, we will need to take our steps carefully if we are to walk the line of blessing our neighbors, promoting holiness, and protecting ourselves from the influences and dangers that might be associated with asking people to bring their families to this location every week.

Please Pray

In light of all this, I and the leaders of LCC are asking you to pray with us and for us as we attempt to make this decision. There are so many signs that are pointing us to believe that this is the opportunity from God we have been waiting for. But there is the very real challenge of figuring out what ministry might look like for us in that part of the city. Ministry feels "safer" on the far south side of Lafayette, but this move has the potential to benefit us financially and also propel us forward in our mission to bring the love of Christ to people who don't know how much they are loved. There are many questions that still need to be answered, so we ask that you pray for us as we attempt to answer them.

I’m beginning to think he has done just that.

In just the past three weeks, we have become aware of the building at 2301 Concord Road and the potential that building has to become our new home.

Now, to take a step back, I need to tell you that when we finished the pledge drive portion of our capital campaign, it was difficult for me to fight back the feelings of disappointment. We had a goal to raise $550,000 in our pledge drive, but the actual pledges we have raised as of today are $135,001.

  • This building is 10,700 square feet. When we started the process last Summer of praying for and looking for a new location for us, our target building size was 10,000 square feet!

Click a photo to see a larger version.

However, in spite of all these awesome things, there is one major concern: location. Of course, they say that location is the most important consideration in all real estate, and from one perspective this location is amazing. The building is visible from the mall, and it is near the Toys R Us.

However, from another perspective, there’s a problem. The building is also right next to an adult gift store and a strip club.

Jen and I have always been confused at the juxtaposition of these two “adult” businesses right next to the Toys R Us, and the thought of putting our church right next to them too, is a little strange and upsetting at first.

Honestly, the thought of moving our church home next door to these businesses has caused a great deal of concern in my heart and in the hearts of other key leaders in our church.

Of course, the entire reason we exist as a church is to try to help people discover life in Christ rather than in all the poor substitutes this world offers us. In that light, it may be a perfect act of grace on our part to move right next to a business that is filled with potentially misguided and needy people each night.

Please Pray

In light of all this, I and the leaders of LCC are asking you to pray with us and for us as we attempt to make this decision. There are so many signs that are pointing us to believe that this is the opportunity from God we have been waiting for. But there is the very real challenge of figuring out what ministry might look like for us in that part of the city. Ministry feels “safer” on the far south side of Lafayette, but this move has the potential to benefit us financially and also propel us forward in our mission to bring the love of Christ to people who don’t know how much they are loved.

There are many questions that still need to be answered, so we ask that you pray for us as we attempt to answer them.

posts.title: The Open Door We’ve Been Praying For?

posts.alt_excerpt: In the second week of our series on perspective, Pastor Jeff shows us how having a gospel first perspective enabled Paul to see that even the worst situations were a potential victory. Speaker: Jeff Mikels :: Passage: Philippians 1:12-30
posts.author: Your Web Servant
posts.content:
In the second week of our series on perspective, Pastor Jeff shows us how having a gospel first perspective enabled Paul to see that even the worst situations were a potential victory.

Speaker: Jeff Mikels :: Passage: Philippians 1:12-30

Speaker: Jeff Mikels :: Passage: Philippians 1:1-11
posts.title: Spin Part 01 :: The Power of Perspective

posts.alt_excerpt: It's amazing how our perspective on things makes all the difference. The same event, viewed from a different perspective can be life-giving or life-draining. In this series of messages, we will track with the teaching of the Apostle Paul through the book of Philippians to find that despite his incredible hardships, he has found a perspective…
posts.author: Pastor Jeff
posts.content:
It's amazing how our perspective on things makes all the difference. The same event, viewed from a different perspective can be life-giving or life-draining.

In this series of messages, we will track with the teaching of the Apostle Paul through the book of Philippians to find that despite his incredible hardships, he has found a perspective on life that gives him unbounded contentment and joy. Would you like to know his secret?
posts.filtered:
It’s amazing how our perspective on things makes all the difference. The same event, viewed from a different perspective can be life-giving or life-draining.

In this series of messages, we will track with the teaching of the Apostle Paul through the book of Philippians to find that despite his incredible hardships, he has found a perspective on life that gives him unbounded contentment and joy. Would you like to know his secret?

posts.alt_excerpt: In this message, Pastor Jeff closes out our capital campaign series with a commentary on what appreciation means when you are talking about a spiritual home. In this message, we celebrate what has happened in our capital campaign and Jeff makes special mention of the people and churches who gave money to help get our…
posts.author: Your Web Servant
posts.content:
In this message, Pastor Jeff closes out our capital campaign series with a commentary on what appreciation means when you are talking about a spiritual home.

In this message, we celebrate what has happened in our capital campaign and Jeff makes special mention of the people and churches who gave money to help get our church started way back in 2006.

Speaker: Jeff Mikels :: Passage: Luke 12:13-34

posts.title: How to Build a Home Part 06 :: Appreciation

posts.title: How to Build a Home Part 05 :: Maintenance

posts.alt_excerpt: Click the each question to see the answer. How much longer is Pastor Jeff planning to stay in Lafayette? This question is one that we used to hear more often than now, but it's still being asked now and then. The bottom line is that Pastor Jeff and his family moved to Lafayette to build…
posts.author: Pastor Jeff
posts.content:
Click the each question to see the answer.

How much longer is Pastor Jeff planning to stay in Lafayette?

This question is one that we used to hear more often than now, but it's still being asked now and then. The bottom line is that Pastor Jeff and his family moved to Lafayette to build a life for themselves and not only to build a church. As long as the church is healthy, as long as they are having a positive ministry, as long as God allows, and as long as he's breathing, he's not going anywhere... even after the church gets its own building.

What will a new building offer us?

New buildings come with new hardships, new responsibilities, and new problems, but they also come with great new opportunities. Just consider the things we might have in a new building that we can't have now:
  • Office space for staff and volunteers to actually work together
  • A counseling room to encourage hurting people
  • A super-exciting, inviting kids area that's actually big enough
  • Bathrooms that are pleasant to be in
  • A food pantry
  • Meeting rooms for community use
  • Enough space to grow
  • Maybe even room for midweek programming like after school tutoring or a daycare!
  • Most of all, it will offer us the chance to invite more people to be part of a church that really feels like a blessing every time they come!

Will this campaign get us a new building?

Not exactly. We are trying to raise $550,000 which isn't enough to buy or build a new building in this area. However, it is enough to purchase land outright or to make a significant down payment on the financing of a new building.This is our first financial campaign and we know that we aren't ready to buy or build, so the main reason we are doing this campaign is to position us and prepare us for whatever the next door is that God will open for us.

How long will it take before we get a building?

Well, that really depends on how this campaign goes. The best case scenario is that we get $550,000 in pledges and a significant amount of cash on hand. If we have enough, then the cash and the pledges will work together to help us secure a construction loan. In fact, the plan is that once the campaign is done, Pastor Jeff will get in touch with the folks at The Cornerstone Fund to ask about financing. He's going to show them the numbers of our campaign and see what kind of loan we could get and what the timeframe might be.However, the most likely scenario is that we won't be able to build until this first campaign is completed three years from now. We could cut corners, but for us to build a high quality building in this area, we will need to have financing in the 2-3 million dollar range, and that will require a down payment of $500,000 cash and a mortgage payment of $10,000 per month. There are ways God could bless us and help us to build sooner, though. If we somehow got blessed with land that's worth $500,000, we would have to pay nothing down because the value of the land would equal 20% of the loan! God might work a miracle in our favor, and we should pray for him to do so. The possibility is for us to be in a building in just a year or two, but the most likely scenario is that we won't be able to start construction for another few years.

What if we don't get enough money?

Strangely, Pastor Jeff is not worried about this. He's fully convinced that God is going to provide for us the amount of money He thinks we should have at this point in time.However, if we don't get enough commitments to reach our goal, that must mean that God's plan for us is different from what we had been thinking. If we don't reach our goal, we will take that as a sign from God of the following things:
  1. It must not be time for us to consider building a building on the southside.
  2. It must be time for us to reconsider how we can maximize the space we are in or look again for alternate meeting space.
  3. Perhaps God wants us to simply save up the money as we keep our eyes open for the opportunity he will bring our way.

How can I make a commitment when my finances are so tight?

When money is tight, it can feel like nothing else matters. So much of our lives is wrapped up in how much available cash we have. When we don't feel like we have financial margin, we feel trapped and helpless. However, there is a solution. Of course, the solution will require changes in our lives. On this front, there are two major things to think about:
  1. Why are my finances so tight?
  2. Do I actually trust God when it comes to my finances?
Regarding point #1, the teaching of the Bible would indicate that God has provided and will provide everything you need. Jesus talks about this in Matthew 6.

(19) “Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moths and vermin destroy, and where thieves break in and steal. (20) But store up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where moths and vermin do not destroy, and where thieves do not break in and steal. (21) For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.

(22) “The eye is the lamp of the body. If your eyes are healthy,your whole body will be full of light. (23) But if your eyes are unhealthy,your whole body will be full of darkness. If then the light within you is darkness, how great is that darkness!

(24) “No one can serve two masters. Either you will hate the one and love the other, or you will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and money.

(25) “Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink; or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothes? (26) Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they? (27) Can any one of you by worrying add a single hour to your life?

(28) “And why do you worry about clothes? See how the flowers of the field grow. They do not labor or spin. (29) Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was dressed like one of these. (30) If that is how God clothes the grass of the field, which is here today and tomorrow is thrown into the fire, will he not much more clothe you—you of little faith? (31) So do not worry, saying, ‘What shall we eat?’ or ‘What shall we drink?’ or ‘What shall we wear?’ (32) For the pagans run after all these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them. (33) But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well. (34) Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own.

Matthew 6:19-34 NIV

This passage indicates clearly that God doesn't want his people to worry about money, about storing up for the future, or even about providing food and clothing for themselves. This is so hard for us to grasp in our greedy materialistic culture, but with a small paradigm shift, things can really come into better perspective. What if you started out with this sentence: God is giving me every dime I need to live the way he wants me to live now. If you started with that sentence, what would be different in the way you handle your money? Perhaps the way God wants you to live right now involves a smaller house, an older car, fewer trips to Starbucks, or even cheaper clothing. Perhaps the way God wants you to live right now involves renting instead of owning or sharing your home with someone else. Perhaps the way God wants you to live right now involves returning to him the first 10% of your income and giving generously and sacrificially to his Kingdom. What if you really believed that God was giving you enough money to do everything he had planned for you? Well, one thing that would change is that you might realize that something you have planned for you is not something He has planned for you. Or, what if you started out with this sentence: God is giving me every skill I need to make the income he has planned for me now. That's another interesting question. I know many people who are looking for jobs, and my heart breaks for them, but I also know that there are many short term options for work. There's lawnmowing, fast food, childcare, factory work, freelance work, and even restaurant work that may just be what God has planned for someone to do just for now until the next opportunity opens up. The bottom line when it comes to the interplay of finances and giving is this: Do I actually trust God when it comes to my finances? Am I living by the financial principles he set up?

For even more practical guidance on this:

Download our Decision Guide

How can I make a commitment when my finances are so tight?

When money is tight, it can feel like nothing else matters. So much of our lives is wrapped up in how much available cash we have. When we don’t feel like we have financial margin, we feel trapped and helpless. However, there is a solution. Of course, the solution will require changes in our lives. On this front, there are two major things to think about:

  1. Why are my finances so tight?
  2. Do I actually trust God when it comes to my finances?

Regarding point #1, the teaching of the Bible would indicate that God has provided and will provide everything you need. Jesus talks about this in Matthew 6.

(19) “Do not store up for yourselves treasures on earth, where moths and vermin destroy, and where thieves break in and steal. (20) But store up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where moths and vermin do not destroy, and where thieves do not break in and steal. (21) For where your treasure is, there your heart will be also.

(22) “The eye is the lamp of the body. If your eyes are healthy,your whole body will be full of light. (23) But if your eyes are unhealthy,your whole body will be full of darkness. If then the light within you is darkness, how great is that darkness!

(24) “No one can serve two masters. Either you will hate the one and love the other, or you will be devoted to the one and despise the other. You cannot serve both God and money.

(25) “Therefore I tell you, do not worry about your life, what you will eat or drink; or about your body, what you will wear. Is not life more than food, and the body more than clothes? (26) Look at the birds of the air; they do not sow or reap or store away in barns, and yet your heavenly Father feeds them. Are you not much more valuable than they? (27) Can any one of you by worrying add a single hour to your life?

(28) “And why do you worry about clothes? See how the flowers of the field grow. They do not labor or spin. (29) Yet I tell you that not even Solomon in all his splendor was dressed like one of these. (30) If that is how God clothes the grass of the field, which is here today and tomorrow is thrown into the fire, will he not much more clothe you—you of little faith? (31) So do not worry, saying, ‘What shall we eat?’ or ‘What shall we drink?’ or ‘What shall we wear?’ (32) For the pagans run after all these things, and your heavenly Father knows that you need them. (33) But seek first his kingdom and his righteousness, and all these things will be given to you as well. (34) Therefore do not worry about tomorrow, for tomorrow will worry about itself. Each day has enough trouble of its own.

Matthew 6:19-34 NIV

This passage indicates clearly that God doesn’t want his people to worry about money, about storing up for the future, or even about providing food and clothing for themselves. This is so hard for us to grasp in our greedy materialistic culture, but with a small paradigm shift, things can really come into better perspective.

What if you started out with this sentence: God is giving me every dime I need to live the way he wants me to live now.

If you started with that sentence, what would be different in the way you handle your money? Perhaps the way God wants you to live right now involves a smaller house, an older car, fewer trips to Starbucks, or even cheaper clothing. Perhaps the way God wants you to live right now involves renting instead of owning or sharing your home with someone else. Perhaps the way God wants you to live right now involves returning to him the first 10% of your income and giving generously and sacrificially to his Kingdom.

What if you really believed that God was giving you enough money to do everything he had planned for you? Well, one thing that would change is that you might realize that something you have planned for you is not something He has planned for you.

Or, what if you started out with this sentence: God is giving me every skill I need to make the income he has planned for me now.

That’s another interesting question. I know many people who are looking for jobs, and my heart breaks for them, but I also know that there are many short term options for work. There’s lawnmowing, fast food, childcare, factory work, freelance work, and even restaurant work that may just be what God has planned for someone to do just for now until the next opportunity opens up.

The bottom line when it comes to the interplay of finances and giving is this:

Do I actually trust God when it comes to my finances? Am I living by the financial principles he set up?

For even more practical guidance on this:

Download our Decision Guide
